narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .

Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel was fantastic - a really great resource for the material, and always available and willing to help out. Can't recommend him highly enough.

Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Good
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel

Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Provided good help when asked, but did very little to make his intentions clear to students. No notification of assignment receipt, or when we would get the graded versions back. Very little communication with students overall.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the class is tough, but great.My thought is that it's extremely useful for quantitative analysis. But I also believe that I'm in the minority among FES students who are concerned about quantitative skills. I think many of my peers are more focused on qualitative skills... writing, policy, etc.

The only reason I did not rate the class (1) Excellent is because it covers quite difficult material, and I don't want to mislead future students. In fact, it is deceptively hard because Professor Gregoire makes it seem so easy . . . until you try the work on your own!

1. Foxâs R Companion to Applied Regression was helpful for navigating R, but the Fox text itself was less helpful than the instructorâs notes, and I rarely used it.10. While the instructorâs notes were somewhat useful, my main complaint about the class is that the concepts were not explained in a way that really helped me to understand them. It would have been extremely helpful if the instructor used more graphical (even simplified graphical) illustrations to demonstrate concepts. The ânarrativeâ style of the lectures did not lend itself well to exploring what is inherently a very visual/graphical subject. More active drawing on the whiteboard during lectures or more utilization of graphical examples would have gone a long way to making the concepts in this class more accessible.14. One thing I did take from this class is how extremely important regression modeling is for making use of environmental data. Use of regression is pervasive in forestry and environmental literature, so even achieving a very basic understanding of the practice was helpful to me.
There should be mandatory lab sessions for this class to build skill on the software, or there should have more exercises in class to help the understanding the subjects.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The software, R... it's open source. So I can use it in the future.
Really useful material taught with clarity and attention to detail.
the professor obviously knows his subject matter well.
1. classes and notes were very clear, organized;2. covered a wide range of topics in regression with a practical twist;

Getting familiar with R was VERY useful, especially since I don't have any programming background. The instructor, while not extremely effective at teaching the material, did set realistic expectations and was very approachable. His sense of humor also made lectures more engaging and enjoyable.
Learning a scripting language that is open access is amazing! While the hurdle of learning R is a steep one, it is valuable. I will definitely use this newly acquired skill in the future.
Learn several functions in the software R.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There's a lot of information to absorb.
It's a huge topic and hard to cover everything in detail. Probably should have rushed the early weeks to get to some of the topics we skipped.

The lectures in this course were boring. The presentation of materiel on the form of a single pdf of notes is not effective. It is difficult to figure out what is important when information is presented this way. The lectures also did not go into much detail about about the why certain types of regression are better or worse.The progress of the course was also slow. At the depth we were covering material we could have covered a lot more.The problem sets at the start of the course were much too simple.Lecture is not the way to teach the R language the professor should present a single intro lecture to the R language and then direct student to the teaching fellow and the copious amounts of online resources to improve there understanding.
The lectures could be a little more participatory/dynamic
Provide examples with more recent/fun data.

This class is almost like two classes in one: the concept of regression and an introduction to the R program/language. Unfortunately, I feel as though I didn't really end up fully understanding either, and I wish it actually would have been two separate classes. My other main complaint is that the TA was very slow in returning homework assignments, and he was not very available for assistance with R (and I think that this is the class where it would have been the MOST helpful to me to get outside help).
I think it may help to have a lab component to this course. Scripting in R is demanding of time and may be helpful to work more closely with others with experience.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes.
N/A
No discussion/lab section for this class.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: He was really pleasant and helpful.

Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel was great. He explains material very clearly, and is willing to answer all sorts of questions. I really appreciated his weekly office hours, because it was very helpful to be able to get his assistance on the homeworks.

Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Apparently Noel led sessions early on helping students to use R. I did not attend these, as I learned R just fine on my own.Noel's lateness in grading or giving feedback on assignments was quite frustrating. Assigned tasks often depended on previous ones, so it would have been helpful to know if the earlier ones had been done correctly. I had to tackle the final project without knowing whether I had done 3 of the 8 assignments correctly. When he did grade homeworks, Noel took points for trivial things like forgetting to put a legend on a chart, instead of actual helpful feedback about the content and procedures.I'm sure thisis a difficult class to grade, but I personally would have preferred more feedback all along to the early R sessions.
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel was helpful during TA sessions and via email.
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Strengths: very helpful during office hoursWeakness: not very responsible with emails
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  As mentioned before, the TA was not very available to help and was very slow with offering feedback on homework assignments.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I want to be able to analyze big data. R is critical to that.
This course is an addition to my quantitative skills course set. Regression is a popular method of analysis and I wanted to be sure to learn about it before graduating.
Absolutely essential. I had seen some of these topics before, but I needed this clear, rigorous treatment to master them. That is why I would have liked to see even more covered.
Good techniques learned for data analysis
I wanted to learn more quantitative tools and this class well matched my expectation.
This course fulfills one of the statistics requirements for the MF degree.

The statistical power gained from this course is extremely important. It will likely help for any science based occupation. Further, it is necessary for the understanding of many peer reviewed articles. Anyone wishing to deal with statistics should have a knowledge base in regression.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To be able to analyze big data with an open source software.
Applicable to my MESc research
I took this course to continue building my analysis skills. I also took it to gain exposure to the R computing program.
To unmuddle my understanding of all types of regression analysis.
Learn how to deal with the data I will collect this summer.
To learn more quantitative tools and be able to understand academic papers better.

I took this course because I recognize how pervasive regression modeling is in the forestry and environmental fields, and I wanted to better understand HOW models are developed. This class helped me to better understand regression modeling, but I think, if taught a little differently, it could have gone a lot further.
To reinforce basic statistical knowledge and to expand my understanding of regression analysis. Also, to learn the programming of R.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: umm... yes... and moreso!
Yes
Yes, the knowledge and skills I gained met my expectations.
Oh sure. Plus, it was a great excuse to learn R.
Yes
Yes

Somewhat. I feel more comfortable navigating the R programming language, and I have a basic understanding of different kinds of regression models. But I still have trouble identifying when to use one model over another, and I still don't feel like I could independently develop an appropriate model based on a large set of data.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: For purposes of seeing the overhead projector, we always had to turn off the lights. I'd prefer to have the lights on during class.I also think that you really do need to have a basic understanding of stats before taking this class.I think TGG is great and so is the software.

Take it if you need the skill. It is a statistics course, don't expect it to be thrilling. It is an excellent course to learn practical regression skills and a great way to begin learning how to use R.
Be prepared to spend time learning the R software - that was the most difficult part for me. The statistics wasn't overwhelmingly challenging, but R was quite frustrating.

Don't daydream, don't surf the web, don't skip class -- it is harder than it seems at first, and the difficulty increases over the semester!And read the textbook only for familiarity. It's a terrific and thorough reference when you need it, but really not a page-turner.
Go for it especially if you want to learn statistical skills in R
1. read the notes carefully after class;2. start the final project early;3. reach out if you are confused.
What's the point in answering these written questions when future students aren't able to see any of my responses??

I'm not sure I would recommend taking this course. If you are interested in learning about regression and how to use R, you could probably find tools and materials online that would be a more productive use of your time. That said, it is useful to have the resources of the professor available, and the instructor WAS very helpful with answering questions outside of class.
Stay on top of the notes. Use the homework to explore R beyond what is assigned. Set aside time for R scripting, silly mistakes can eat up a good deal of time.
